item.name: Agrippa
entries: An agrippa is a 5-foot-tall infernal tome full of pages made of human or elf skin. Said to hold the heat and fury of helltire in its pages, an agrÄ±ppa is a potent magical item that can cause madness and death. Due to the size and power of the book, the agrippa is usually kept suspended from a ceiling in chain.

entries.name: Attunement
entries: If you spend 48 hours over a period of 6 days or less reading the book, make a DC 13 Intelligence saving throw. If you fail, you acquire indefinite madness (roll on the chart on DMG page 260). If you succeed, you are attuned to the agrippa, you gain two points of Intelligence as does your maximum for that score.

entries.name: The Bound Devil
entries: Once you are attuned, the devil bound to the tome appears before you. Often, the devil will be an imp, a mistortune devil, a harvester devil or an infernal succubus. The devil acts as an adviser and assistant and appears whenever the book is opened. If the devil travels more than 30 feet from the book, it is sent back to the Nine Hells and cannot retum for one week.

entries.name: Spells
entries: Every agrippa contains powerful spells.

The DM is free to choose them, but in general, the following spells are in most agrippas: {@spell banishment}, {@spell contact other plane}, {@spell gate}, {@spell Planar binding}, {@spell plane shift}, {@spell scrying}, and {@spell teleportation circle}.

entries.name: Truenames
entries: The book contains an enormous list of truenames, but most of them are incorrect or out of date. If you spend 10 hours poring over the list of truenames, make a DC 20 Intelligence check. A success means you have discovered a truename.

entries.name: Truename Benefits
entries: The agrippa gives special benefits when the wielder casts a spell on a creature whose truename the caster knows:

entries.name: Contact Other Plane
entries: The book gives you advantage on your saving throw.

entries.name: Scrying
entries: The target automatically fails the saving throw.

entries.name: Sigil Sequences
entries: The agrippa contains sigil sequences for use with a teleport circle spell to 5 different locations, at least one of which is in the Nine Hells.

entries.name: Using an Agrippa
entries: Some agrippas are pure evil and reject any reader who is not lawful evil. They have magical traps that feeblemind and burn any undesirable who touches it. The agrippa described here accepts anyone.

entries.name: Origin
entries: Agrippas are usually made by spellcasting archdukes on the ascent. Eventually, they grow so powerful that they no longer need the agrippa. It is given to an underling or stolen and, centuries later, it winds up in the hands of intrepid adventurers.

entries.name: Possible Creators
entries: Archdukes likely to have created an agrippa include Tartach, Mephistopheles, and Armaros.

entries.name: The Devil Underlings
entries: The devils with listed truenames are likely completely subservient to the archdevil and will be less than thrilled to find out someone else knows their truename as well.

item.name: Baatorian Green Steel Plate Mail
entries: Deep in the bowels of scalding infernal mines, veins of green-flecked iron run through the jagged rock of Avernus. When alloyed with steel, this metal can be used to create weapons of amazing strength and sharpness.

entries.name: Obtaining Green Steel
entries: Items made of baatorian green steel are extremely light and imbued with infernal magic. They are highly sought after, but are very difficult to obtain. Most acquire one through a merchant in the city of Sigil, or snatch one off of a scorched Blood War battlefield.

Baatorian plate mail weighs only 12 pounds and is considered medium armor. Because it is so light, wearers are not subjected to the movement penalties and strength requirements for heavy armor and not have disadvantage on stealth checks.
This armor is extremely desirable for barbarians, clerics, and rangers.

item.name: Baatorian Green Steel Longsword
entries: Deep in the bowels of scalding infernal mines, veins of green-flecked iron run through the jagged rock of Avernus. When alloyed with steel, this metal can be used to create weapons of amazing strength and sharpness.

entries.name: Obtaining Green Steel
entries: Items made of baatorian green steel are extremely light and imbued with infernal magic. They are highly sought after, but are very difficult to obtain. Most acquire one through a merchant in the city of Sigil, or snatch one off of a scorched Blood War battlefield.

Forged in Avernus, these blades are highly sought after because they are almost weightless and they are magical in nature. Rogues and those who are engage in two-weapon fighting find these blades to be invaluable.

item.name: Baatorian Lute
entries: Crafted by an erinyes, these lutes produce sounds like none heard by mortal ears. Once per day, the bard can cause black, feathered wings to grow from an ally's back, giving them a fly speed of 40 until the end of the bard's next turn. When the bard issues bardic inspiration, the target's eyes glow red until the inspiration die has been used.

item.name: Baatorian Whiskey
entries: Baatorian whiskey is the preferred drink of devils involved in the Blood War. Non-fiends who imbibe it must make a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or take 17 ({@damage 5d6}) poison damage. Additionally, many who drink it begin to hear the infernal whispers of Glwa, delivering devil propaganda in the infernal tongue. To have such evil poured into the mind of a mortal causes the victim to make a DC 14 Charisma saving throw or they suffer long term madness (roll on the chart on DMG page 260).
Almost all baatorian whiskey is made by the agents of Glwa. Crates of it are delivered to devil armies for a modest fee.

item.name: The Blade of Fiery Might
entries: Created by efreeti wizards, this blade was stolen long ago from Marrake al-Sidan al-Hariq ben
Lazan, Sultan of the Efreeti and ruler of the City

entries.name: of Brass
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. It has the following additional properties.

entries.name: Flaming Blade
entries: This weapon does an additional {@damage d8} fire damage when it hits a target.

entries.name: Truesight
entries: The wielder has {@sense truesight} up to 120 feet.

entries.name: Control Fire
entries: As an action, you can expand or extinguish a five-foot cube of fire in one direction.

entries.name: Fire Shield (1/Day)
entries: As an action, you can wreathe yourself in flames that grants you resistance to fire damage. In addition, whenever a creature within 5 feet of hits you with a melee attack, the attacker takes {@damage 2d8} fire damage. This effect lasts for 10 minutes or if you use a bonus action to dismiss it.

entries.name: Sentience
entries: The Blade of Fiery Might is a sentient, lawful weapon with an Intelligence of 13, a Wisdom of 12

entries.name: and a Charisma of 17
entries: It has hearing and {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.
The weapon can speak and understand Common and
Ignan, and can communicate with its wielder telepathically.

entries.name: Personality
entries: Because it was wielded by royalty for so long, the Blade of Fiery Might uses flowery, regal speech.
At one time, the blade was lawful evil. After it was shattered, the blade was reassembled by the kindly Wind

entries.name: Dukes of Aaqa
entries: The Blade learned from their patience and has become more tolerant, although it still has a sinister streak now and then.

item.name: The Blasphemous Libram
entries: An influential tome devoted to Glasya, the original Blasphemous Libram contained rituals and spells designed to cultivate a large following of warlocks known as the Daughters of Blackest Night. Their duty was to seek out beautiful humanoid specimens for Glasya to keep in her palace of Osseia.

The first Blasphemous Libram was written by a witch named Eraea. Eraea hated the divine and wanted to re move Asmodeus from the Nine Hells because he bore a divine spark. She and her followers were slain, but the Libram survived.
Since that time, other warlocks have created transcrip tions of the Libram. There are at least 13 copies in exis tence, each of which is slightly different. Most of them contain:
A record of the warlocks who have made pacts with Glasya.
Details on how to perform rituals to draw energy from Glasya, how to make pacts, and rituals to aid in the earch for exceptional beauty.

There is a large section detailing the magical process of transforming a seduced or corrupted mortal into a Hellsworn minion. Daughters of Blackest Night diligently practice carving their unique vile runes in the heads of mortals. It is those runes that power the Hellsworn and link them to Glasya.

Each book covets soul energy and itself is an infernal contract. As long as the Libram is intact, those who have made pacts through it and die go right to Hell. When unattended and forgotten on a shelf, Glasya can connect with it and issue forth a call to the soul. Those who are evil and prize beauty find themselves dreaming of the book and of the re wards it offers. The book likes to seek out inexpe rienced warlocks that it can corrupt.

entries.name: Destroying a Libram
entries: The Libram can only be destroyed through a battle of wills with the Glasyan sentience of the tome (a DC 20 Charisma check). Failing this battle results in Stolen Beauty. The tome draws out the most appealing qualities of the target and siphons it to Glasya herself. The character loses 10 points of Charisma perma nently.
Destroying the book will free all Hellsworn, whose devil traits swiftly fade away in black wisps. They are mortal once again, and their soul is bound to no one.

item.name: The Book of Fire
entries: When this book is open and not in a container, any words spoken aloud within 30 feet appear as writ- ten words on its pages. You can wipe a page clear of words by touching one finger to the page anad uttering the word: "Burn".

The Book of Fire contains a written record of the Nine Hells that reveals a lot of information about Moloch, Titivilus, Lilith, and other arch- dukes. This book is famous for its detailed and vivid account depicting the lurid activities of Moloch, Geryon and the Hag Countess.

item.name: Brimstone Cloak
entries: Smelling faintly of sulfur, this magic cloak helps to protect the wearer from fire and poison.

entries.name: Resistance
entries: When you wear the cloak, you have resistance to fire and poison.

entries.name: Brimstone Rebuke (1/Day)
entries: As a reaction, when you are damaged by a creature within 60 feet of you that you can see, the creature must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. It takes {@damage 3d10} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

entries.name: Brimstone Step (1/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, briefly surrounded by a cloud of brimstone, you teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see.

item.name: The Chalice of He Who Was
entries: The shimmering, golden Chalice of He Who Was, sometimes known as the Benevolent Vessel, is a legendary item that is said to be able to purify the soul.

entries.name: Healing
entries: When the chalice is filled with water, those who drink from it can gain healing. It affects each creature only once per day. When you use an action to drink from the chalice, you regain up to 50 hit points.

entries.name: Curative Properties (3/Day)
entries: Those with diseases, ailments, or lost body parts can drink from the chalice and heal all conditions completely. Any missing limbs or body parts are regenerated.

entries.name: Raise Dead (1/Month)
entries: Water poured from the chalice into the lips of a dead creature who has been dead no longer than 30 days acts as a raise dead spell.

entries.name: Redemption
entries: When an evil creature drinks from the chalice, they must make a DC 16 Charisma saving throw or become good. If a creature makes the saving throw, they cannot be affected by the chalice for 24 hours.

entries.name: Divine Resurrection
entries: It is said that the chalice can be used to resurrect He Who Was and restore him to his former glory.

item.name: The Cloak of Batna
entries: This cloak contains the vestigial remains of Batna, an ancient archdevil slain by Asmodeus.

entries.name: Sentience
entries: When the hood is up, Batna can send the wearer insights and impulses. She can also confer with the wearer in their dreams.

entries.name: Flight
entries: While wearing this cloak, you have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks. You can grip the edges of the cloak with both hands and use it to fly at a speed of 40 feet. If you ever fail to grip the cloak's edges while flying in this way, you lose this flying speed.

entries.name: Devil Bat
entries: You can use your action to cast {@spell polymorph} on yourself, transforming into a {@creature devil bat|EmirkolsGuidetoDevils}.
While in the form of the devil bat, you retain your Intelligence, Wisdom and Charisma scores. The cloak can't be used this way again until the stroke of midnight.

item.name: The Codex of Betrayal
entries: The Codex of Betrayal is an ancient tome written in golden ink in the Celestial language. This Codex gives a full account of Asmodeus' rebellion against He Who Was. It was written by a mysterious individual known as Brother Eiulo, said to be the last surviving servitor of He Who Was.

entries.name: Sunbeam (1/Day)
entries: Once per day, a creature can hold up the Codex and cast {@spell sunbeam}.

entries.name: Conjure Deva (1/Day)
entries: A creature attuned to the Codex can read from it to summon a deva  as per the conjure celestial spell, except that the deva does not have to obey verbal commands.
This is a specific deva with a glowing tattoo of chalice on his chest. This deva is very protective of the Codex and does not suffer fools lightly.

entries.name: Truenames
entries: It is said that each book contains the truename of an archduke. Book four is said to contain the truename of Baalzebul himself.
The codex is broken into four books, each containing several dozen chapters.

entries.name: Book One
entries: Titled "A Chronicle of He Who Once Lit Our Way, His Heavens, and the Earth Below," this book details the days preceding Asmodeus's uprising.

entries.name: Book Two
entries: "A Chronicle of Bloodstained Heavens," a record of the uprising and the war itself.

entries.name: Book Three
entries: "A Chronicle of Unquenchable Flames and Unbreakable Maledictions," which details the earliest years of the Nine Hells under Asmodeus, the devils' reactions to the curse, and the establishment of the initial hierarchy.

entries.name: Book Four
entries: "A Lexicon of Murderers Most Hated and Vile," a list and description of every devil about whom Brother Eiulo could learn, even the most minor fact.

item.name: Devil Talisman (Unsanctified)
entries: There are a number of different types of devil talismans, unsanctified talismans being one of the more common varieties. Each has a large bloodstone set on a tantulhor backing. Usually, the tantulhor is carved in a way to reflect the devil it is connected to.

entries.name: Finding the Truename
entries: Those who peer into the bloodstone will see glowing letters in the Infernal language. That is the devil's truename. Those who can read the truename and speak it have the ability to attune to the devil talisman.

entries.name: Guardians
entries: There is often other writing on the talisman that describes the devil it is linked to. Reading any of it aloud will cause devils to appear in {@dice 1d4} rounds, intent on killing the holder of the talisman. The type of devils appearing ranges anywhere from imp to pit fiend, depending on who the devil linked to the talisman is and who it could get to agree to be a guardian of it.

entries.name: Summoning the Devil
entries: Once attuned, the wearer can spend one minute to attempt to summon the devil. The wearer must make an opposed charisma check against the devil. If you or an ally who knows the truename has cast a {@spell magic circle spell} and the circle is within 15 feet of you, the devil has disadvantage on the saving throw. If the devil succeeds, it is not summoned and you cannot try to summon it again for nine days. If the devil fails, you have summoned it. The type of devil determines how long it stays with you.

items: Archdevil. One task, taking no longer than one minute.

entries.name: Protection
entries: The devil cannot directly harm you in any way when you are wearing the talisman. Bond. The wearer shares a telepathic bond with the devil, even if the devil is on another plane. Controlling the Devil. If you concentrate as if you were casting a spell using the concentration rules, you can mentally force the devil to do what you want, as long as the com- mand is not suicidal. When you are not concentrating, the devil is free to do as it will.

entries.name: Dismissing the Devil
entries: You can dismiss the devil with an action, sending it back to the Nine Hells. You cannot attempt to summon it again for nine days.

entries.name: True Death
entries: If the devil is slain permanently, the devil talisman explodes. The wearer must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 64 points of fire damage, 32 points on a successful save.

item.name: Devilbane
entries: A gem crafted by powerful celestial beings, each of these deep green gems have a light green fire burning at its center.
Devilbane gems are a magical safeguard that act as a barrier to prevent devils from overrunning the

entries.name: Material Plane
entries: Only devils who are summoned or travel through a permanent portal can leave a layer that has a devilbane gem active on it.

entries.name: Damage to Evil
entries: Evil creatures who get within 15 feet of the gem take 20 radiant damage per round. Those who touch it are affected as per a disintegrate spell.

entries.name: Powered by Prayer
entries: A devilbane gem is powered by divine magic. Three times per day, a prayer to a good-aligned deity that is at least one minute long keeps its power unming. If a prayer is not uttered, the gem's effects cease. It takes 3 hours of prayer to resume the ef fects.

entries.name: Disrupting the Gem
entries: Distupting the gem can be done by shattering it or removing it from the layer it is on. The Gem of Stygia. There is one devilbane gem in Stygia, guarded in a holy, fortified keep. Levistus gets around the effect by hiring mortals and half-fiends, who sail ships through portals to round up souls for the archdevil.

item.name: Devilhusk Armor
entries: Devilhusk Armor is armor covered in vicious barbs that is made from the hide of a barbed devil. While wearing this armor, you gain a +l bonus to AC.

entries.name: Barbed Hide
entries: At the start of each of its turms, the wearer deals 5 ({@damage 1d10}) piercing damage to any creature grappling it.

item.name: Fiendblade (infernal)
entries: Infernal fiendblades are designed to slay angels and to link a mortal to a powerful archdevil, to act as their proxy or to further their agenda.
You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a creature of the celestial type with it, the celestial takes an extra {@damage 2d6} slashing damage.

entries.name: Transformation
entries: Once the wielder draws blood with a fiendblade, they take on cosmetic physical traits of the archdevil that the blade is conected to. Connection. The wielder is telepathically linked to the archdevil. They can ask questions and receive advice if the archdevil is in the mood for it.

entries.name: Vulnerability
entries: Being splashed with a vial's worth of holy water does {@damage 2d8} radiant damage to the wielder. Soul Pact. Once attuned, the soul of the wielder is marked by the archdevil linked to the fiendblade. When the wielder is slain, their soul travels to the Nine Hells and is the property of the archdevil to be either tortured or rewarded.

item.name: Greenstone Amulet
entries: Under the guidance of the great crafter Tymphalos, the duergar of Phlegathos created a number of amulets of proof against detection and location out of an infernal mineral known as greenstone. They discovered that using greenstone has conferred additional powers to the amulets.

entries.name: Psychic Protection
entries: The amulet gives you resistance to psychic damnage and you are immune to the {@condition charmed} condition.

entries.name: Anti-Detection
entries: While wearing this amulet, you are hidden from divination magic. You can't be targeted by such magic or perceived through magical scrying sensors.

item.name: The Heart of Mephistopheles
item.reqAttune: mephistopheles created this item for agents of his in the mortal realms. the heart is a ruby one-foot-wide and contains a personality modeled after the psyche of mephistopheles himself. it advises cultists and allies

entries.name: Dominate Monster (1/Day)
entries: The wielder can cast {@spell dominate monster} with a Wisdom save DC of 18.

Lightning HellBolt (3/Day). As an action, a stroke of fiery lightning bursts out from the Heart and forms a line of fiery lightning 100 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw or take {@dice 8d6} lightning and {@damage 3d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. This power ignites all objects in the area that are flammable. Infernal Hellscape. All devils within one mile of the Heart are immune to the spell banishment.

entries.name: Unbreakable
entries: The Heart is impervious to harm. The only known way to destroy one is for a cleric or paladin of a good deity to cast {@spell raise dead} or resurrection on the heart. This will make a crack appear in the heart, allow- ing it to take physical damage: AC 14 HP 30. Once re duced to 0 hit points, the Heart of Mephistopheles ex plodes in a 50 foot radius. All creatures in the radius must make a DC 20 Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 10d6} fire damage, half as much on a save.

item.name: Hellpiercer
entries: A hellpiercer is a devil-slaying magic arrow containing a reservoir of couatl blood that explodes on impact. When a devil takes damage from a hellpiercer, it must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes an extra {@damage 6d10} piercing damage and is {@condition blinded} with radiance until the end of your next turn. On a successful save, it takes half damage and is not {@condition blinded}.
Once a hellpiercer deals its extra damage to a creature, it has used up the couatl blood and becomes a non-magical arrow.

item.name: Hellstones
entries: Also known as "Ulith", hellstones form in the infernal rifts of Nessus. These fiery red gems are some of the hardest gems known to exist.

entries.name: Dangerous to Handle
entries: They are lit by an inner hellfire and they do {@damage 2d6} fire damage to any non-evil creature that touches one.

entries.name: Infernal Enchantment
entries: Embedding a hellstone on a melee weapon gives that weapon a +1 non-cumulative bonus to hit and damage. Hellstones tend to warp the weapon to make it more sinister in appearance.
Sometimes, the wielder feels the pull of evil tugging at their soul.

entries.name: Deadly
entries: A weapon with a hellstone will never deliver non-lethal damage.

item.name: Howling Dagger
entries: Crafted from the chains that once bound a mighty primordial, there are 100 howling daggers in existence. When unsheathed, any howling daggers you own orbit around your body as tortured devil faces shriek audibly from their pommels.

entries.name: Unique Attunement
entries: When you are attuned to one howling dagger, you are attuned to them all.

entries.name: Howling Aura
entries: Once attuned, any unsheathed howling daggers that you own orbit your body.

entries.name: Howling Fury
entries: As a bonus action, when you hit an enemy within 25 feet of you with an attack, each howling dagger in your Howling Aura flies to the target, deals one damage, and returns to your aura.

entries.name: Howling Admonishment
entries: When a creature starts its turn within 25 feet of you, any howling daggers in your aura deal 1 slashing damage to the target and return to your aura.

entries.name: Acquiring More
entries: When a howling dagger is within 50 feet of you, you can make a DC 20 Charisma (Intimidate) check. If you succeed, any howling dagger within 50 feet of you becomes part of your aura. If they are attuned to somebody else, you must make an opposed Charisma check. The daggers flock to and orbit around the winner and another such contest cannot take place for 24 hours.
Currently, all of the howling daggers are owned by the five assassin devils known as the Stygian Masque.

item.name: Howling Bandolier
entries: A long baldric with many loops that magically holds up to 100 daggers.

entries.name: Howling Release
entries: As a bonus action, the wearer can draw up to 100 daggers from this bandolier.

item.name: Lucifuge
entries: You gain a +2 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit a creature of the ficnd type with it, the fiend takes an extra {@damage 2d6} slashing damage. Should the wielder ever altack an archdevil, he blade deals an extra {@damage 4d6} slashing damage instead of {@dice 2d6}.

entries.name: Transformarion
entries: When you attune to this weapon the wielder gains homs, a thin red tail and their skin tuns red. This effect goes away when the wielder is not at- tuned to Lucifuge.

entries.name: Connection
entries: The wielder is telepathically linked to the sentience of Lucifuge, a devil child killed by Asmodeus. It empathically conveys child-like curiosity and hatred for all devils.

entries.name: Goal
entries: Lucifuge wants to kill Asmodeus. If it does so, the sword turns to ash and the wielder is granted one wish, as per the spell.

item.name: Malefactor
entries: Crafted from baatorian green steel, this mace's head is shaped like the skull of a screaming horned devil and the end of the haft is shaped like a barbed devil claw. Malefactor has {@hit 2} to hit and damage and it does{@damage  + 2d8} bludgeoning damage to demons.
Liar The wielder has advantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks.

entries.name: Powers
entries: Malefactor can cast each of the following spells once per day: {@spell Fear}, {@spell flame strike} - this version of the spell does necrotic damage instead of radiant, trueseeing, and {@spell wall of fire}.

entries.name: Plane Shift (3/Day)
entries: When the wielder says "Cauldra Azavistos" out loud, it triggers a plane shift spell that leads to an infernal fortress known as the Fortress of Malevolence (detailed below).

entries.name: Sentience
entries: Malefactor is possessed of a slight sen- tience and it can communicate empathically with the wielder. If it is displeased, it can fill the wielder's head with strong emotions. The wielder must make a DC 17 Charisma saving throw or drop the weapon

entries.name: Personality
entries: Malefactor was created to kill demons. It loathes chaos and values order Male- factor especially appreciates those who are crafty.

entries.name: The Fortress of Malevolence
entries: This fortress, located in a volcano of Phlegethos, has a magi cally cool interior and it contains five bedrooms, two guest rooms, an audience chamber, a banquet hall, a kitchen and a bathroom with a {@item bag of devouring} incorporated into the toilet.
There are a number of interesting things in the Fortress:

items: Maggot Mattress: One guest room has a bed with a mattress made of sewn demon skin stutfed with dead black maggots. Black Dragon Corpse: In another bedroom, the remains of a black dragon are suspended from the ceiling by nine hooked chains.
Teleport Chamber: There is a teleportation chamber containing a permanent teleport cirde.
Mirror of Lifetrapping: This mirror holds: A {@creature vargouille|VGM}, Celiskus Graystaff the human wiz ard, Phylbar Sunstrider the human paladin and lalicen, the remorseful tiefling.

item.name: Nightmare Harness
entries: This harness is studded with platinum and precious gems that burn with an inner fire. Summon Nightmare (1/Day). If you are attuned to the harness, you can use an action to summon a night- mare through the harness, who willingly serves as a mount for up to 6 hours. You can dismiss it with an action. If the nightmare is slain while summoned in this way, the harness crumbles to dust.

entries.name: Mistreatment
entries: Each harness is linked to a specific nightmare, each with their own personality. The nightmare will turn against those who treat it poorly.

entries.name: Pilfering Gems
entries: If you try to steal a gem off of the harness, you will plagued with dreams about being chased by a nightmare. Every night, your hit point maximum is reduced by 5 until you are dead. This condition can be cured with a greater restoration spell.

item.name: Ravages
entries: The powers of good have their own answer to poison: ravages, magical traumas which can twist the moral corruption of evil creatures to cause them physical pain. Ravages are enchanted variations of holy water that affect only evil creatures and work similarly to poison.

entries.name: Golden Ice (Contact, 400 gp)
entries: This crystalline substance is cold to the touch but never melts. Evil creatures who come in contact with golden ice must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or their interior hardens into golden ice and they are {@condition restrained} for 6 hours. The condition ends if the creature takes damage.

entries.name: Celestial Lightsblood (Ingested, 1,700 gp)
entries: This rare, ethereal substance is of a pure silvery color. Evil creatures who ingest this ravage suffer no effect until they commit an evil deed (the DM decides what qualifies as evil). When this occurs, the creature must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 9d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

entries.name: Unicorn Blood (Injury, 1,400 gp)
entries: Donated by a noble and giving unicorn, this blood loses its potency if the uni- corn is slain. An evil creature subjected to this ravage must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 7d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

item.name: Ruby Rod of Asmodeus
entries: The ruby rod can be wielded as a weapon, a mace that has +5 to attacks and damage. Every hit is a critical hit.

entries.name: Appearance
entries: This scepter is a 4-foot shaft carved from solid ruby. Along its length are the names of good deities and angels spelled in reverse and stained with dark blood. The bottom is jagged, as if the item was snapped from a larger piece, while the top is a clawed fist clutching a skull.

entries.name: Rulership
entries: The Ruby Rod is the symbol of office for the ruler of Nessus. Whomever wields it rules Hell.

entries.name: Aura of Might
entries: Anyone attempting to attack the wielder must first succeed on a DC 20 Charisma saving throw. Failure means that the attacker does not attack, but bows down, becoming {@condition prone} until the start of the next turn. Once a saving throw is successful against this aura, you are immune to it for 24 hours.

entries.name: Line of Lightning
entries: As an action, the wielder can cast {@spell lightning bolt}.

entries.name: Line of Acid

entries.name: Reverie of Nessus (1/Day)
entries: Once per day, the wielder can be encased in a 5-foot-radius spherical wall of force. The area 50 feet around the sphere (but not within it) becomes an {@spell antimagic field}. This effect lasts for 3 rounds. At the start of the first round, the wielder is automatically purged of any unwanted enchantment spells or effects. At the start of the second round, the wielder is purged of any diseases, poisons, or physical maladies (including lost body parts). At the start of the third round, the wielder gains the effects of a Long Rest. This ability triggers as a reaction if the wielder ever fails a save against an unwanted enchantment spell or effect, such as charm person.

entries.name: Creation
entries: Crafted fiom a single ruby of incredible size, it was drenched in the blood of a thousand mortal sacrifices, refined in Tiamat's acidic drool, and polished with the tears of 777 angels. Inside of it is a shard from the seed of evil, the pulsing heart of all that is foul that lies at the bottom of the Abyss.

entries.name: Lesser Rods
entries: It is known that his aspect has a replica of the rod, which seems to suggest Asmodeus has the ability to create facsimiles.

item.name: The Vallis Crystal
entries: At first glance, this shapeless bit of crystalline stone appears less valuable than the silk it is wrapped in. Within its facets lies an entire world. If you hold the crystal in your hand, you can use an action to teleport yourself and up to 8 willing creatures within 20 feet to the world inside the crystal. There are 6 different locations on the world you can appear at. Anyone who travels to the world of Vallis in this way can magically teleport back outside the crystal as an action.

entries.name: Answer Prayer
entries: If you are attuned to it, you can hear the prayers of the people inside. Once per day. you can answer them per the rules of a commune spell. Holy Assist. Once per day, you can spend an action to contact someone in the crystal who can give you advice, giving you advantage on a skill check that involves ntelligence, Wisdom or Charisma.

entries.name: Heal Self
entries: Once per day, as an action. you can use the collected divine energy of their prayers to heal yourself for {@dice 3d8 + 8} hit points.

entries.name: Raise Dead
entries: As an action. once per month you can use the Vallis Crystal to cast {@spell raise dead} with no need for the components. When doing so, you must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. If you succeed, one random humanoid living in Vallis dies and their life force fuels the spell. If you fail the save, {@dice 1d100} random humanoids of Vallis die. In either case, a diamond worth 500 gold in the world of Vallis vanishes, used up by the spell.

entries.name: Created by Devils
entries: Perhaps one of the greatest feats the devils have ever achieved is the creation of the Vallis Crystal. With the aid of Armaros, Asmodeus placed an entire mortal world inside the crystal.

item.name: Developmental Hellfire Wand
entries: This wand has 7 charges. While holding it, you can use an action to expend one of its charges to cast the Hellfire spell (save DC 15) from it. The wand regains {@dice 1d6 + 1} expended charges daily at midnight. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll a {@dice d20}. On a 1, the wand crumbles into ash and is destroyed.

When you successfully hit with the wand, a stu- dious infernal succubus (usually either Nandima the Inquisitive Succubus or Brimshadow the Over- worked Incubus) appears and wants to quiz the wielder on how the wand is working and if any tweaks should be made. They write down notes on a 4 foot-long scroll with a quill made from the bloodied feather of a swan.
When you use the wand, roll {@dice 1d6} for an additional effect:

items: The wand backfires, dealing {@dice 2d6} fire (hellfire) damage to you.
Smoke fills a 5 foot radius centered on you heavily obscuring the area for 1 minute.
A hovering pinpoint of hellfire hovers in the air, issuing bright light in a 50 foot radius for 1 minute.
After the spell does its damage, the hellfire becomes a fire bat that fights as your ally. It fades away after one minute.
The wand regains the charges it just spent.
